Gal Aga
Gal Aga
postsData.content:
Last year, I spoke to the CRO of a $120M ARR SaaS who KILLED their Sales Enablement tech budget and moved back to Google Drive. Here's what went wrong (and why he called SE a "big lie"):


CONVO RECAP:

CRO: The entire concept of Sales Enablement is a big lie.

Me: Ok, you got my attentionâ€¦ elaborate?

CRO: Look at the tools and the ways people fill this role. I need my AEs to multithread, run better calls, build champions better, etc. But weâ€™re paying [Top 3 enablement vendor] for soooo many bells and whistles, and what we end up with is basically a glorified Google Drive.

Me: What do you think went wrong?

CRO: These tools are solving for the wrong problem. Content Management isn't Enablement. It is a marketing/sales alignment problem, not a sales effectiveness one. Too many of the Enablement folks out there are really more L&D experts or marketers than sales experts, so the enablement tech giants focus on them.

Me: So, what is Sales Enablement in your mind?

CRO: Solving for better deal execution, a better workflow with our buyers, and insights about deals (not just how content is being used). And sales experts should run this. Our team ends up downloading and emailing content to clients, ignoring the tech. I don't need to pay $70,000 for what is essentially GDrive.


MY THOUGHTS:

That might sound harsh, but letâ€™s be honestâ€”heâ€™s not wrong.

Weâ€™re not enabling Sales if weâ€™re not improving the Buyer-Facing Process.

Weâ€™re not enabling Sales if weâ€™re not enabling Buyers.

Years of â€˜Growth At All Costsâ€™ made us lose sight of what matters.

Sales Enablement should NOT be about:

- how well the enabler knows how to train people
- how many case studies and ebooks we build
- how well we organize information internally
- how fast our team can find this information

Sales Enablement SHOULD be about:

- how well the enabler understands real selling and buying pains
- how many assets we build that can truly help the buying process
- how well reps deliver relevant, digestible information to buyers
- how effectively our team can help buyers make decisions

We could get away with it when the salesperson was the source of knowledge.

We could get away with it in a ZIRP, hire fast, and just get reps out there era.

We could get away with it when buyers weren't a group of 11 confused stakeholders, each using ChatGPT to form their own opinion, navigating 100 vendors per category, and facing CFOs in every approval process.

But itâ€™s a different world nowâ€¦

69% of sales teams MISSED 2024.

And if you think sales is complex, youâ€™re missing the pointâ€”Buying is.

Sales is hard because buyers are failing.

Because buyers are confused, stuck in indecision, and face unhelpful reps.

An effective enablement role and tech should FIX THAT.

Content Management and L&D are not enough.

We should support Buyers as much as we support Sellers.

Flip the script from Sales to Buyer Enablement.

comments.commentText:
It's kinda a roundabout way when you actually think about it; intentions are good- we equip our sellers with countless trainings and info, which then gets passed onto the client... why not just start there? Focus on the end client and their experience first since that's the ultimate goal anyway?

Gladis leading the charge on this shift from seller enablement to buyer enablement

Meredith Chandler 100%, and it can only start there. If we donâ€™t understand our own buyer journey, our buyerâ€™s friction and how to create a better experience that supports buying jobs to be done, we wonâ€™t be able to help sellers sell. Just inviting Sandler to give a lecture and flooding reps with content is not enough.

It all starts with the buyer. We say customer-centric and translate it to sales-centric. "How fast & easy can I sell?" Instead of the basics of selling: SMYKM and buyer enablement. SE nowadays chops everything in tiny pieces and loses the bigger picture: there is no ONE buyer journey (at least not in my B2B high value business and I guess nowhere else either except transactional sales). So it's like playing chess and move with every move your buyer makes to both win. I see too many sales use AI infused SE and not get the conversion rates you would expect so just increase the volume. That's not where we need to land...

You wouldnâ€™t check yesterdayâ€™s weather to decide if you need an umbrella today, right? 

So why are businesses still relying on outdated data to make real-time decisions?

I once worked with a retail brand that constantly battled inventory chaosâ€”running out of bestsellers while slow-moving products gathered dust. Their reports were always a day late, and by the time they reacted, customers had already walked away.

We switched them to real-time analytics, and the transformation was instant. They could track demand shifts as they happened, tweak pricing dynamically, and optimize stock levels in the moment.

Result? 20% fewer stockouts, higher sales, and less waste.

This isnâ€™t just a retail thing. Every industry today needs to move at the speed of NOW.

Banks need to stop fraud before it happensâ€”not after the damage is done.
Marketers need to adjust campaigns on the flyâ€”not post-mortem.
Manufacturers need instant supply chain insightsâ€”not crisis reports.

Real-time data isnâ€™t a luxury anymoreâ€”itâ€™s the difference between leading the game and playing catch-up.

Is your business still running on yesterdayâ€™s data? Letâ€™s talk about it!

postsData.content:
The trajectory of my corporate career was truly crazy. 


If you dropped in at any random moment during my first 5 years,

you'd likely be witnessing a dumpster fire.

My entire corporate career from entry level to the C-Suite, was 12 years In total!

Far too much happened in a very short period of time.

Here it is unfiltered:

2005-2006: 1st sales job, 6 months, quit
2006-2007: 2nd sales job, 18 months, fired
2007-2008: 3rd sales job, 18 months, quit
2008-2008: 4th sales job, fired after 3 days
2008-2009: 5th sales job, 6 months, out of business
2009-2009: 6th sales job, 9 months, fired
2010-2010: 7th sales job, 5 months, quit for leadership role w/ 4th company
2010-2012: 8th sales job, sales leader, 24 months, quit
2012-2014: 9th sales job, director, 50% pay increase, 18 months, quit
2014-2017: 10th sales job, CCO, 120% pay increase, 36 months, fired

The path is rarely smooth or predictable, and you keep moving forward anyway, no matter what.

You learn a lot more from the failures than any success.

Your truthfully,

comments.commentText: There is no linear career path.

Theres tonnes of value in learning what we donâ€™t want, what we donâ€™t prefer & what we donâ€™t excel at & this is the stage many humans are currently operating - itâ€™s socialised & normalised - wildly successful ppl (who love their lives & create results way beyond what the mainstream implies is possible) do not focus on failures & do not claim they learned more from them than their successes - itâ€™s a mindset shift that doesnâ€™t land w the majority but where we are focused is where we are going & knowing that explains why so few of us create results beyond average

Kathleen what youâ€™re saying is that itâ€™s so easy to just know what you want. Divorces? Bullshit, donâ€™t marry someone you donâ€™t want to be with. Bad job? Should have known it would be like that. Learning from experiences that are bad, avoid the bad experiences and donâ€™t waste time learning from them. I wonder how many people would agree with you sentiment? Itâ€™s just not accurate. Smart people learn from people that are where they want to be or have been where they donâ€™t what to end up. Thatâ€™s why coaches whoâ€™ve experienced troubled times are so damn good. They help avoid those mistakes and decisions.

I hear you, Michael the issue is weâ€™ve all been socialised to believe that low emotional states are normal (it happens early, before age 6/7 for most of us) & that our preferences (which are highly aligned w following what feels best to us, which we all practiced as children) donâ€™t matter - we mistakenly believe that the worse we feel, the more progress weâ€™re making, that struggling our way thru something is more valient than enjoying ourselves & we donâ€™t associate our emotional state with 1.our perception of our own value & 2.our ability to perceive next logical steps towards what we do want - thatâ€™s why life is a slog not bc it has to be

Are You a Multitasker or a Monotasker?  

In todayâ€™s fast-paced world, weâ€™re constantly juggling emails, meetings, deadlines, and social media notificationsâ€”all while trying to stay productive. It feels like weâ€™re getting more done, but are we really?

Hereâ€™s the hard truth: Multitasking is a myth!  Our brains arenâ€™t wired to handle multiple tasks at once. What we call â€œmultitaskingâ€ is actually task-switchingâ€”jumping between tasks at lightning speed. This constant switching doesnâ€™t make us more productive; it actually makes us less efficient, more prone to mistakes, and mentally exhausted. â€

Science backs this up! Studies show that our brains work best when we focus on one thing at a time. This is called monotasking, and it leads to deeper focus, better results, and reduced stress. 

If youâ€™ve been feeling overwhelmed by endless tasks, itâ€™s time to shift gears! Here are 4 powerful strategies to stop multitasking and start working smarter:

 1. Time Blocking â³ â€“ Break your day into dedicated time slots. Focus on one task for 20â€“30 minutes before moving to the next. This method improves concentration and helps you get more done with less stress.

 2. Batch Your Emails  â€“ Instead of checking your inbox every 5 minutes, set specific times (e.g., morning, afternoon, and evening) to read and respond to emails. This stops constant distractions and gives you more uninterrupted work time.

 3. Minimize Distractions  â€“ Silence notifications, close unnecessary tabs, and work in a quiet environment. Your brain needs deep focus to produce high-quality work!

 4. Declutter Your Workspace  â€“ A messy desk leads to a cluttered mind. Keep your workspace organized to improve mental clarity and efficiency.

The key to real productivity isnâ€™t doing more at onceâ€”itâ€™s doing things with focus and intention!

Overthinking has ruined more lives than actual failure.

How many times have you:

Overanalyzed a decision so long that you missed the opportunity entirely?

Talked yourself out of something before you even started?

Watched someone dumber than you succeed just because they actually took action?

Yeah. That last one stings.

Hereâ€™s the thing, high achievers struggle the most with this.

Because the smarter you are, the better you are at making failure sound logical.

Hereâ€™s how you can break the overthinking cycle:

1ï¸âƒ£ Give yourself no more than 10 seconds to make decisions. If you sit on it for days, youâ€™ll talk yourself out of it.

2ï¸âƒ£ Assume youâ€™ll probably fail, or at least suck initiallyâ€¦ then do it anyway. Why? Because failing forward still beats standing still.

3ï¸âƒ£ Start tracking â€œdecisions madeâ€ instead of just â€œdecisions perfected.â€ You donâ€™t win by being perfect. You win by moving first.

Most people lose, not because they made the wrong decision, but because they never made a decision at all.

Take action today homies!

comments.commentText:
Great message Ned Arick.

I like to tell clients that what if "failure" is actually natures mechanism to teach you?

When I was younger (long ago ) I was a team lead for an industrial chemical company and in charge of equipment maintenance.

The 1st time someone called me to help them fix something I had no idea what I was doing. I didn't even know all the machine names.

That 'failure' made me gather all the names and find the manuals.

The next time someone asked me for a part number, I failed. So I created a list of all the part numbers.

When someone asked for the name of other service techs that have worked on particular equipment, I didn't know. So I started making a contact list.

Over time, failure became complicated. Because nature had shown me all the ways I could fail so that I could fix them.

In that way, failure isn't really thing. Its just a lesson to help us adapt and overcome.

This is one of the weirdest cold emails I've ever got. It's good, but terrible at the same time. Breakdown:

The gist is I sort of like the different writing style (it cuts through the noise) but the fundamentals are just off.

What's right:

The way it's written definitely makes me keep reading. I don't know if it's because I'm amused by the writing style, but it definitely gets my attention.

What's wrong with this:

1. Subject line: If you're using that as a subject line, you better be able to back it up and tie it in with the copy. Otherwise, it's like using "re:" â€“ people hate it.

2. Where you found me: I'm all for humor and cheesy lines, but not if you can see right through them. This + using text-based "expressions" is a bit of a turn-off.

3. Prospect fit: Would you offer leads to a lead gen agency? Probably not. At least not framed like this.

4. Company name formatting: This is where they really lose me. Not formatting your company names to remove how they're formatted on LinkedIn is a deal-breaker.

5. The CTA asks for a call: I don't love this unless you've nailed the offer + relevance + social proof. Plus, how about that sign-off?

The military theme is kinda odd too...I think it could've been executed differently.

Props on the social proof and good deliverability though.

What do you think of this? Am I being too harsh?

postsData.content:
Incredibly, almost every single top seller follows this exact career trajectory:

1. Started out selling a really crappy product

2. Moved to selling / leading teams at a great product

Why is this such a dangerous combo?

If you've only played a video game on Rookie Mode, you can't master it. It's only when you win the game in Legendary Mode that you actually understand it.

Similarly, if you've never sold a really mediocre product, you often lack the creativity and grit to figure things out when it gets hard. You don't understand the concept of "make  happen" and are reliant on great marketing, product, inbounds, support, brand to pave the way to deals.

Once you've learned how to use only your own sales skills to win deals, then you can literally sell anything.

Add to that a really strong product, brand, and momentum ... that's where the magic happens.

I'll never forget when, one of the best sellers I've ever worked with, moved from a shitty adtech company where we crushed deals together ... to Pinterest. I visited him a few months into his new role, where he had quickly become one of the top sellers.

Finn and I had worked together for 2+ years and cleverly found a bunch of hacks to increase email opens / responses by using a bunch of data enrichment, had to go through all sorts of gymnastics to get deals done.

When he got to Pinterest, he was stunned that the cold email every single sales rep used basically read:

===

Subject: Mark - Finn from Pinterest

Body: "Hi Mark - do you want to learn about how to run ads on Pinterest to grow your brand? Let's chat."

===

After years of trying every trick in the book to get meetings, and being damn good at it,
suddenly Finn went from playing on Hall of Fame mode to Rookie mode.

But instead of getting lazy and complacent, he continued to use his hard earned skills to outperform every other rep.

That's whatis taking about here. And it is an incredible profile to look for.

postsData.content:
When a VC-backed founder becomes a 'thought leader' right after their '9-figure exit', here's what they aren't telling you 

- We sold the company for $100M (their "9-figure exit")
- But we had to pay our Series A/B investors $63M
- We also paid our seed investors $10M
- Then, we divided $27M between 3 - as we're 3 co-founders
- That's $9M each
- With 37% capital gains tax; that's another $3.3M less
- So $5.7M pre-debt
- But since we didn't take a salary for the first 2 years and had to take a $500K personal loan --> We made $4.8M in the end

The truth about SaaS exits and "9-figure exits"

Reality check:

- 7 years of your life
- 65% dilution
- Lost control of your company
- $686K per year pre-tax
- Endless board meetings
- 120 people to manage
- $800K monthly burn rate
- Constant fundraising stress

Meanwhile, bootstrapped founders:

- Keep 100% ownership
- Hit $3M-5M ARR
- Take home $1M-3M/year
- Run lean teams (<10 people)
- Build with customer money
- Focus on unit economics
- Exit option for $30-40M always available
- Complete freedom to choose their path
- No board to answer to

The real "9-figure" number to focus on?

The 99% of VC-backed startups that don't even get this far.

Build for freedom, not exits.

comments.commentText:
And yet pain, not pleasure, is the more powerful motivator.

This idea comes from Loss Aversion, a behavioral psychology and economics concept.

In practical terms, this means:

People are more likely to take action to prevent failure than to chase success.

Fear-based marketing (e.g., "Avoid these mistakes...") often gets more engagement than aspirational messaging.

Urgency and scarcity (e.g., "Limited spots left!") trigger stronger responses because they tap into the fear of missing out (FOMO).

So, if you want to drive actionâ€”whether in business, coaching, or self-improvementâ€”framing a message around avoiding pain or loss is often more effective than promising pleasure or gain.

Joe Glick
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 5 â€“ CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making todayâ€™s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! Emphasizing multidisciplinary expertise is key to redefining our approach to AGI. Excited to see where this leads!

postsData.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
postsData.content:
I'm 43.

After 12 years bootstrapping, growing Groove to $5M ARR, and leading a team of passionate builders, I've made just about every entrepreneurial mistake in the book.

Here are 10 pieces of brutally honest founder advice (I wish someone had told me day one):

1. Create one true believer. To get traction, you don't need 1000 customers or investors. You need one customer who believes in you. Find them, deliver exceptional value, and they'll become your biggest evangelist.

2. Data beats intuition. Intuition means scaling only with gut feelings. Data means gathering real customer feedback and using it to become customer-obsessed. Let the data do the heavy lifting.

3. Take calculated risks. Bootstrapping a SaaS company was terrifying. But I didn't jump blindly. I tested, learned, and built a path. Run experiments first. Focus on small wins to reduce uncertainty. Big dreams are scary, but calculated risks are where growth happens.

4. Systematic execution is the requirement. When I launched Groove, I planned, tested, and refined that business. I was methodical, sometimes to a fault. If you're not systematic, someone else who is will out execute you. Success isn't genius... it's process.

5. Handle feedback thoughtfully. In tough situations, write the response or email, then wait 24 hours before sending. You'll almost always revise it with a clearer headâ€”and build better relationships in the process.

6. Being a student is the fastest way to grow. I worked with every customer I could, I learned everything they could teach me about their needs. Find successful companies in your space, and study what works for them. Shortcuts don't existâ€”but learning accelerates the journey.

7. Never waste a good crisis. In the late 2010's our growth dropped from 100% to 30% monthly growth. It felt devastating, but I used it as an opportunity to rethink the approach. We created efficiency throughout the company and became incredibly focused. Six months later we rebounded with our strongest quarter ever.

8. The most important decision you'll make is choosing what to focus on. The best investment wasn't in features, it was in understanding customers. Your priorities will shape your business more than anything else. Choose wisely.

9. The top performers live in the details. The difference between good and great is in the small things. At Groove, our retention grew because we paid attention to the details others overlooked (like response times, onboarding flow, customer feedback loops).

10. No milestone makes you successful. There's no void to fill. When I hit my first million in ARR, I thought the achievement would fix everything (my doubts, my stress, my uncertainty). Reality check: it didn't. No number can make you feel fulfilled. True satisfaction comes when you realize you're building something valuable all along.

What principle had the biggest impact on your business journey?

Haha.. bootstrapping is an art. I call myself and you and all the other bootstrapped guys - artists. It's tough and most of the time people don't understand how we run our tight ship. But we do and are happy about it..

postsData.content:
An objection can feel like a slap in the face (if you don't know how to handle it)

How I handle top 10 sales objections:

Every objection is an opportunity for discovery - peel the onion.

1 â€œEmail me in 3 months"
- What will happen in 3 months?

2 â€œIâ€™m not interested"
- Before I leave - Is <challenge> a priority right now? if not, what is?

3 â€œToo expensiveâ€
- It sounds like you're comparing this to what you already have or just the value isn't there for you. Which one is it?

4 â€œWe donâ€™t have the budgetâ€
- Budget aside, is this even close to a priority for 2025?

5 â€œIâ€™m locked into a contract with a competitorâ€
- Anything youâ€™d want to improve with your current solution?

6 â€œtried it & it didnâ€™t work for usâ€
- Could you tell me more about what didnâ€™t work?

7 â€œWe just signed a contract with a providerâ€
- Would you want to explore other options before renewal, just to compare?

8 â€œWe already use a competitorâ€
- Would you be open to hearing 3 ways we differ?

9 â€œAll set for nowâ€
- Just so Iâ€™m clear, whatâ€™s working well that you feel all set on?

10 Iâ€™m too busy right now
- Is there a better time, or should I send a quick summary by email?

Don't fight the objection, get to the real why.

That's the art of verbal judo.

How do you handle objections?

PS. I`m, follow me for tips on how to drive revenue from LinkedIn & Email
